Lines, and IOM to Advance Cooperation through Renewable Energy2025-08-21T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T05:43:01ZLexisNexisSharp Corporation and Sharp Energy Solutions Corporation Sign Memorandum of Understanding with Mitsui O.S.K. Lines, and IOM to Advance Cooperation through Renewable EnergyTOKYO

TOKYO, Aug 21, 2025 - (JCN Newswire) - Sharp Corporation and Sharp Energy Solutions Corporation (*1) (hereinafter referred to as "Sharp") have signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) regarding the cooperation through renewable energy to advance improved access to basic services in displacement-affected areas in the Republic of Kenya (hereinafter "Kenya"). This MOU is signed with Mitsui O.S.K. Lines, Ltd. (Headquarters: Minato ward, Tokyo, hereinafter referred to as "MOL"), and the International Organization for Migration (*2) (hereinafter referred to as "IOM"), in conjunction with the 9th Tokyo International Conference on African Development (*3) (TICAD 9).

The MOU also stipulates that the Parties will explore innovative solutions and technologies to strengthen climate resilience of vulnerable communities in Kenya.

Sharp has been promoting ESG-based management, and this MOU aligns with its corporate philosophy "to contribute to the benefits and welfare of people throughout the world." Sharp will continue to address societal challenges and fulfill its commitment to social contribution by utilizing its unique products solutions and technologies.

*1 Sharp Energy Solutions Corporation is a subsidiary of Sharp Corporation responsible for energy solutions. Headquarters: Yao City, Osaka Prefecture. President and Representative Director: Hirozumi Gokaku.

*2 The International Organization for Migration (IOM) is a UN agency that addresses global migration issues. IOMJapan Chief of Mission : Ritsu Nacken.

*3 The TICAD 9 will be held from August 20 to August 22, 2025, at Pacifico Yokohama (Yokohama City, Kanagawa Prefecture). It is organized by the Japanese government in collaboration with the United Nations, the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP), the World Bank, and the African Union Commission (AUC).

Sharp Sustainability global website: https://global.sharp/corporate/eco/

Source: Sharp Corporation

urn:contentItem:6GHW-X4T3-RY6D-V435-00000-00NEC and ClimateAi Develop Conceptual Model to Promote Climate Change Adaptation in Agriculture2025-08-19T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T05:43:01ZLexisNexisNEC and ClimateAi Develop Conceptual Model to Promote Climate Change Adaptation in AgricultureTOKYO

TOKYO, Aug 19, 2025 - (JCN Newswire) - NEC Corporation (NEC; TSE: 6701), in collaboration with ClimateAi, a San Francisco-based startup that built the first climate resilience platform, has developed a conceptual model to estimate the effectiveness of climate change adaptation measures for cocoa and rice cultivation in Africa. In this project, ClimateAi's long-term climate change forecasting technology, which models both the impact of climatic factors on agricultural production and the effectiveness of adaptation measures, was combined with NEC's expertise in agricultural technology (agritech) to successfully quantify the impact of climate change on agriculture and clarify the return on investment for adaptation measures.

This achievement will be showcased at the TICAD Business Expo & Conference (Japan Fair), one of the thematic events of the Ninth Tokyo International Conference on African Development (TICAD 9) to be held in Yokohama, Japan, in August 2025, conveying the significance of utilizing digital technology to address the challenges facing African agriculture (*1).

Background and purpose

Globally, while greenhouse gas emission reductions and credit trading are actively being conducted to mitigate the effects of climate change, the implementation of adaptation measures to prevent or reduce damage caused by climate change has not yet progressed. This is due in part to the difficulties involved in assessing the investment cost-effectiveness of implementing adaptation measures.

Notably, although the agricultural sector is an industry highly susceptible to climate change, estimating the return on investment for adaptation measures, such as the introduction of irrigation facilities or changes in crop varieties, has thus far proven difficult due to the wide range of factors affecting crop growth, including temperature, water, and soil.

NEC and ClimateAi have developed a conceptual model that analyzes various factors affecting agricultural growth using AI and calculates the economic return on investment for adaptation measures. Utilizing this model enables the implementation of adaptation measures that focus on areas where positive effects are expected, promoting local agriculture efficiently and sustainably.

Overview

This newly developed conceptual model was used to analyze adaptation measures targeting the cultivation of cocoa and rice in various locations in Africa. Africa is the world's largest cocoa producer, with agriculture being one of its major industries. However, due to the impacts of climate change, the cultivation environment for cocoa and rice is expected to change significantly in the coming decades. This initiative focused on the following three adaptation measures to examine their ability to maintain and enhance yields and create economic value in a changing climate.

- Introduction of irrigation facilities

- Changing to climate-adapted varieties

- Changing of planting time for traditionally cultivated varieties

Some of the analysis results can be verified through interactive demonstrations. As an example of potential applications for this conceptual model, it is envisioned that international organizations and development banks providing local agricultural support will utilize it to explore farmland in recipient areas and estimate the effects of implementing adaptation measures.

Beyond this example, the system is designed to cater to the needs of various stakeholders involved in agriculture, enabling them to make data-driven decisions.

Results and future prospects

The utilization of AI made it possible to analyze the cost-effectiveness of adaptation measures, such as the introduction of irrigation facilities and changes in cultivation varieties in rice farming across various regions, as well as effective adaptation strategies for cacao cultivation.

Significant funding is required to advance climate change adaptation in agriculture. It has been pointed out that in addition to the need for financial support from international organizations, development banks, and governments, the mobilization of private investment is necessary. To provide continuous funding, it is essential to quantify the investment returns from adaptation measures and to conduct proper monitoring and intervention following their implementation.

While exploring opportunities for collaborations with businesses that provide irrigation equipment and seedlings, NEC and ClimateAi aim to leverage digital technology use cases to promote financing for climate change adaptation and expand data-driven agritech businesses.

- Adaptation finance business

Support for understanding risks to agricultural yields to reduce entry barriers for the private sector / Support for evaluating business feasibility for financing

- Agritech business

Support for agricultural producers and managers of climate change adaptation / Support for climate change adaptation in the upstream (seed and agricultural material businesses) and downstream (processing businesses, etc.) of the agricultural supply chain

- Other business

Support for climate change adaptation in the infrastructure industry and manufacturing supply chains

The results of this initiative will be announced at the TICAD Business Expo & Conference (Japan Fair) and other events to gather feedback from the market and proceed with discussions toward commercialization. Going forward, NEC and ClimateAi will work together to scientifically assess the impact of climate change on agriculture and present concrete solutions to achieve sustainable agriculture and food security. Both companies will continue striving to solve global agricultural challenges through technological innovation and data utilization.

NEC's new business development, under the key message "The future is ours to shape," is advancing NEC Open Innovation (*2) through diverse co-creation with a wide range of startups and partner companies. NEC's collaboration with ClimateAi is one such initiative. By uniting innovative technologies with cross-domain collaboration, NEC continues to create new social value and shape the future.

(*1)NEC to participate in "TICAD Business Expo and Conference" and thematic events for TICAD 9 https://www.nec.com/en/press/202508/global_20250805_03.html

(*2)NEC Open Innovation

https://www.nec.com/en/global/innovation/index.html

About ClimateAi, Inc.

ClimateAi is a climate adaptation and resilience platform purpose-built for the agriculture, food, and consumer goods sectors. It combines AI-powered weather modeling with phenological and water-scarcity data to deliver highly localized, crop-specific agricultural impact insights across the short, medium, and long term. With deep expertise in climate-agriculture interactions and a client base that spans agricultural and consumer-goods multinationals as well as agricultural investors, ClimateAi turns complex climate data into actionable insights. For more information, visit ClimateAi at https://www.climate.ai

About NEC Corporation

NEC Corporation has established itself as a leader in the integration of IT and network technologies while promoting the brand statement of "Orchestrating a brighter world." NEC enables businesses and communities to adapt to rapid changes taking place in both society and the market as it provides for the social values of safety, security, fairness and efficiency to promote a more sustainable world where everyone has the chance to reach their full potential. For more information, visit NEC at https://www.nec.com.

Source: NEC Corporation

urn:contentItem:6GG2-B953-RV07-M0JM-00000-00The effects of China's Belt and Road Initiative investments on mitigating climate risks in partner countries2025-09-16T05:43:02Z2025-09-16T05:43:02ZLexisNexisPg. 229-249The effects of China's Belt and Road Initiative investments on mitigating climate risks in partner countries

Data availabilityAll data are available upon application.

Declaration of conflicting interestsThe authors declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

FundingThe authors disclosed receipt of the following financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article: Qilu Institute of Technology Project Funding (QIT23TP029).

ORCID iDsFarooq Muhammad Sabil https://orcid.org/0000-0001-7034-0172Feroze Nazia https://orcid.org/0000-0001-5206-7643Faisal Feroze https://orcid.org/0009-0003-6597-3727

Farooq Muhammad SabilFeroze NaziaCheng Tong ShunFaisal FerozeABSTRACT

The One Belt, One Road (OBOR) program is a major step toward making the idea of a worldwide community that shares common interests a reality. Nevertheless, a number of OBOR member nations are located in areas that are particularly vulnerable to the effects of climate change. The infrastructure developments linked to the OBOR program have prompted several Western countries to express concern that these nations may become even more vulnerable to the effects of climate variability. The impact of Chinese foreign direct investment (FDI) on climate change risks in OBOR member nations is explored in this article, which also analyzes the processes at work. Examining panel data from 65 partner countries spanning 2004–2020, this research examines how China's FDI affects host countries’ capacity to handle climate change risks, with a particular emphasis on each country's vulnerability risk. Important results from the research comprise: China's direct investment in OBOR regions strengthens the climate resilience of partner countries by reducing their vulnerability to climate change. Countries with lower or medium incomes, those in close proximity to China, and those that have free trade agreements with China feel the benefits of Chinese investments more acutely. Consistent with OBOR's guiding philosophy of sharing development outcomes and promoting global governance, the positive impacts of OBOR investments can be explained in part by rising incomes and stable governments. Contrary to claims of “carbon emissions transfer” and evidence that environmental sustainability is central to the OBOR project, investments made under the OBOR have decreased climate vulnerability without increasing local carbon emissions. The research findings and policy suggestions in this article provide light on the current function of China's OBOR program and suggest ways to ensure its long-term viability.

FULL TEXTIntroduction

In order to promote high-quality cooperation under the Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) and to build a community with a shared future for humanity, China is focusing on enhancing the ability and effectiveness of participating nations to address climate change risks. Launched in 2013, the BRI is a plan to build infrastructure and promote economic growth across continents by connecting land and sea routes across Asia, Europe, and Africa. To combat climate change, promote green development, and encourage peaceful cohabitation between humans and nature, the 20th National Congress of the Communist Party of China stressed the necessity of active engagement in global governance.

Several nations that are part of the BRI are situated in areas that are particularly vulnerable to the effects of climate change, including more frequent and severe weather events, higher sea levels, and altered patterns of precipitation.

The possibility for negative social and economic impacts on local ecosystems and climate is a common source of concern for these nations. But the BRI opens doors for partner nations to high-tech infrastructure and resources, so they can better withstand the effects of climate variability.

Several Western nations are skeptical of the BRI's joint development initiatives, arguing that the infrastructure projects could make participating nations more vulnerable to climate change and that China's investments in the BRI cause partner countries to transfer carbon emissions. This is despite the fact that the BRI has the potential to bring about positive changes. This mistrust has made certain countries, areas, and UN agencies reluctant to participate in the BRI.

The purpose of this research is to find out how vulnerable the BRI nations are to climate change and to determine if the investments made by China in the BRI have helped at all. New viewpoints and scientific facts bolstering the BRI's function in battling climate variability are offered by the study, which delves into the beneficial externalities of China's BRI initiatives. In addition, the report analyzes how China's BRI investments have affected carbon emissions, refuting assertions made by certain Western nations over the “carbon emissions transfer” linked to BRI projects. This research helps fill gaps in our knowledge about the BRI's sustainable development potential and its role in tackling global concerns by delving into these issues.

Literature review and research hypothesesLiterature review

Economic and social growth, as well as possible environmental implications, are all part of the literature on how China's BRI investments have helped partner nations reduce their climate risk. Myint (2019) found that participating nations can experience growth and development thanks to BRI investments, which enhance infrastructure, trade, and connectivity. Concerns over the potential direct and indirect impacts on the environment, especially in light of climate change, have been voiced in response to the breadth and depth of the project (Hameiri et al., 2018; Jones and Zeng, 2019; Myint, 2019).

There is a risk that some BRI projects will increase carbon emissions and biodiversity loss, while others will encourage sustainable infrastructure and clean energy development in partner nations (McCarthy, 2020). According to Jones and Zeng (2019), the BRI has the ability to help reduce climate risk through its investments in renewable energy projects across different regions. Investments in conventional energy projects, including those using coal or oil, have significant negative impacts on the environment due to their enormous carbon footprints and other negative aspects (Wei, 2022).

The influence of the BRI on climate hazards is highly dependent on how the initiative interacts with environmental regulations in the countries that are partners. Social and environmental problems might worsen in partner nations with inadequate governance and lax regulatory systems (Gardner et al., 2020: 2). Problems with land acquisition, insufficient community involvement, and insufficient environmental impact assessments are just a few examples of the obstacles that BRI investments may encounter (Gelpern et al., 2021). To keep social and environmental standards intact, project funding and decision-making processes must be open and transparent (Gonzalez-Vicente, 2019: 509).

In this context, it is essential to address governance models and international cooperation frameworks underpinning the BRI . Julien Chaisse's (2023) study on US development finance elucidates the competitive dynamics between US and Chinese development strategies, highlighting how governance models influence international cooperation. This comparative perspective underscores the distinct approaches taken by different countries in fostering global development and economic partnerships. Moreover, Jean-Michel Marcoux and Julien Sylvestre-Fleury's (2022) work on state-owned enterprises and government procurement sheds light on the regulatory complexities and strategic behaviors of state-owned enterprises within the BRI framework, emphasizing the importance of transparent procurement processes and robust regulatory oversight (Marcoux and Sylvestre-Fleury, 2022). Additionally, the study by Chaisse and Jamieson Kirkwood (2020) on BRI-related investment treaties provides a comprehensive analysis of the legal and institutional arrangements that facilitate international investments under the BRI, stressing the need for coherent and consistent legal frameworks to enhance investor confidence and ensure sustainable development. Incorporating these insights enriches the article’s governance analysis, offering a more holistic view of the BRI's operational environment and its implications for global governance and international cooperation.

Ecological disruptions caused by BRI projects, such as habitat destruction and biodiversity loss, are critical for assessing climate resilience. To address these shortcomings, the article will incorporate a broader range of data sources, including international databases and independent environmental assessments. Engaging with non-Chinese sources will help mitigate potential state bias, providing a balanced view of the BRI's environmental impact. Additionally, Yan's (2023) study on labor rights in Asia-Pacific trade agreements highlights how labor clauses in free trade agreements influence labor policies and sustainable development. Chaisse's (2023) research on corruption in foreign investment explores how international investment tribunals address corruption, informing the analysis of governance and climate finance in the context of foreign investments and Sustainable Development Goals. Qian's (2022) article on investment treaties and sustainable development provides insights into how international investment law affects climate financing, and Denolf's (2008) study on corruption's impact on foreign direct investment (FDI) explores the relationship between corruption, governance, and economic growth. These studies will significantly broaden the article's scope and depth, offering a richer analysis of the governance factors influencing climate finance in the context of sustainable development and corruption.

The complex impacts of the BRI on climate risk reduction are shown by case studies of individual initiatives in various locations. Chinese investments in renewable energy projects in Southeast Asia have helped diversify energy sources and decrease reliance on fossil fuels. These projects include hydropower, solar electricity, and wind farms (Alami and Dixon, 2022; Alami et al., 2021). Traditional energy projects, such as coal plants, can raise carbon emissions and add to air pollution; thus, there are worries about the possible detrimental effects of investing in these projects (Alami et al., 2021). Clean energy projects and better regional energy connectivity could be fostered by BRI investments in Central Asia (Lenton et al., 2008, 2019). But there are certain initiatives that could impede the shift to low-carbon economies and clash with global climate goals, such as building fossil fuel infrastructure (Kulp and Strauss, 2019). The BRI has backed massive hydropower projects in South Asia, which could lead to increased economic activity and cleaner energy. But there are worries that these initiatives will harm river ecosystems and the people who live nearby (Schindler et al., 2023).

Chinese investments in solar and hydroelectric projects in Africa have shown promise for facilitating economic development and expanding access to renewable energy (Osei-Kyei and Chan, 2016: 170–171). However, deforestation and habitat disruption are just two examples of the long-term environmental repercussions that large-scale operations can cause (Pettis, 2022). The BRI has the potential to improve trade and economic growth in Africa by investing in trains and roads; nevertheless, there is a risk that these projects would increase emissions and cause other environmental problems (Taylor and Zajontz, 2020).

Solar farms and other renewable energy projects funded by the BRI have the ability to lessen the region's reliance on a single energy source and increase resilience to climate variability. But spending money on gas and oil infrastructure could make us rely on fossil fuels for a long time and sabotage our attempts to switch to greener energy (Carmody et al., 2022).

According to the research, the effects of the BRI on the environment and climate change risk can differ between regions, project types, and partner nations’ governance systems. Projects can have varying impacts on environmental problems and the ability to achieve global climate targets. Some projects help reduce climate risk and promote sustainable development, while others can make things worse.

Through in-depth case studies and longitudinal analyses, future research should strive to offer more thorough and nuanced evaluations of the environmental implications of BRI investments, with a focus on climate risks. To make sure that China's investments assist in fighting climate variability and build resilience in partner countries, BRI projects should prioritize sustainable development and follow social and environmental norms (Clowes and Kavanagh, 2022).

Incorporating insights from Chaisse and Mitsuo Matsushita's (2018) work on the normative and strategic implications of the BRI highlights the geopolitical strategies of China, emphasizing how the BRI shapes global trade dynamics and economic cooperation. Additionally, examining the regional dynamics of BRI through the lens of Chaisse and Pasha L Hsieh's (2023) study on Asia-Pacific regionalism provides a detailed analysis of the BRI's impact on regional trade and governance. Analyzing EU-BRI interactions through Burnay and Raube's (2023) work on the European Union's strategic responses to the BRI enriches the understanding of the initiative's global implications. These studies collectively underscore the critical role of the BRI in shaping the future landscape of global trade liberalization and economic cooperation.

Proposed hypothesis

According to the research evaluation, socioeconomic factors and local natural conditions both impact the dangers associated with climate change. There is much evidence that FDI affects local socioeconomic dynamics, which implies that the inflow of foreign money has the potential to alter the social and governmental landscape of the host nation. For example, research has demonstrated that FDI boosts host countries’ capacity for good governance and overall development. Construction of infrastructure, project management, industrial clustering, and cultural interchange are just a few ways in which the nations that are co-building the BRI are impacted by investments, which are a type of FDI. By creating jobs, promoting urbanization, and impacting local customs and lifestyle choices, these endeavors have the potential to mold the social fabric of a nation.

In addition, co-building countries can tackle issues like insufficient funding and outdated technologies with BRI investments. Better social and governance capacities that follow allow for better local reactions to climate hazards. Therefore, BRI investments may help co-building nations become more resilient to climate variability by enhancing their capacity to handle climate risks. Therefore, we postulate the following: Hypothesis 1: Financial investments from China's Belt and Road Initiative can help nations that are co-building mitigate the effects of climate change.

Increases in both GDP and per capita income are mostly attributable to FDI. People in co-building nations, particularly those with lower incomes, stand to benefit economically from China's direct investments in BRI projects because of the jobs they generate, the knowledge they transfer, and the speed with which they industrialize. Greater financial resources allow locals to take stronger measures to mitigate the effects of climate change, making them less susceptible to its negative effects.

Theoretically, the nations that are part of the BRI could see an increase in income and public funds as a result of the investments made by China. This fiscal base lessens the likelihood of vulnerability by bolstering the ability of governments and citizens to adjust to climate change. Living circumstances stabilize and response capabilities grow as wages rise and infrastructure is strengthened, mitigating the impact of climate change disasters. This leads us to offer the following hypothesis: Hypothesis 2: Countries that are part of the Belt and Road Initiative can increase their revenue and so be less vulnerable to the effects of climate variability.

Co-building countries can benefit from China's investments through the BRI in terms of social and economic development as well as political stability. Embracing traditional cultural principles like “harmony without uniformity” and “seeking common ground while reserving differences” helps partner nations maintain calm societal atmospheres. Governments are able to devote more funds to adaptation efforts to climate variability as a result of the decrease in social and political disputes brought about by these cultural exchanges.

Hence, the following theory is put forth: Hypothesis 3: Countries that are part of China's Belt and Road Initiative may see a decrease in their vulnerability to climate shifts as a result of investments that strengthen their governments.

Some have argued that the investments in energy-intensive businesses that are part of China's BRI will cause partner countries to produce more carbon emissions. Nevertheless, both previous studies and the actual implementation of BRI green development efforts indicate that these investments do not substantially increase carbon emissions. Actually, green development and reductions in carbon emissions intensity are common outcomes of China's investments in areas where the two countries are working together to construct.

Hence, the following theory is put forth: Hypothesis 4: Investments under China's Belt and Road Initiative have not significantly contributed to the carbon emissions levels of co-building countries.

Research designData sources and variable constructionData sources

The research mandates that 65 member nations of the BRI serve as the study's sample. The scale of China's FDI in these partner nations is the main explanatory variable, using data obtained from the Statistical Bulletin of China's Overseas Direct Investment published by the Ministry of Commerce and made available through the Guotai’an database.

The susceptibility risk of the 65 partner countries to climate change, as determined by the Global Adaptation Initiative's Country susceptibility Index (ND-GAIN), is the main dependent variable. There are two primary aspects of adaptation that make up the ND-GAIN index: vulnerability and preparation. There are three ways to measure vulnerability: sensitivity, exposure, and adaptive capacity. Food, water, health, ecosystem services, human habitat, and infrastructure are the six pillars of life that this method takes into account when assessing a nation's susceptibility to the detrimental effects of climate change. As a result, the 34 ND-GAIN climate change vulnerability indices provide a reliable assessment of the degree to which a nation is at danger of experiencing climate change catastrophes.

World Bank and World Governance Indicators (WGIs) Global Governance Data databases provide national-level control variable data. The research only covers the years 2004–2020 because before that year China's investments in the BRI were relatively small. First, we removed data points that were missing information. Second, to reduce the impact of outliers, we applied a winsorization technique to the continuous variables at the 1% level. This means that the extreme values (top and bottom 1%) of the data were adjusted to the nearest value within the 1–99% range, a common practice in the literature to mitigate the influence of extreme data points. The final dataset is an imbalanced panel suitable for empirical analysis.

Variable construction

The research takes into account factors including exposure, sensitivity, and adaptive capability to conduct a thorough evaluation of the hazards associated with climate shift susceptibility in various nations. By taking into account factors such as exposure to physical risks, sensitivity due to dependence on climate-sensitive sectors, and adaptive capacity to mitigate potential losses, the study assesses the susceptibility of nations to climate-related disruptions and disasters using the ND-GAIN Vulnerability Index, which was developed by the University of Notre Dame (Chen and Chen, 2017). Countries involved in the BRI might use this data to assess their vulnerability to climate variability. A consistent format is used to convey the index data, with a base value of 100.

Chinese foreign direct investment (CFDI) is the stock of Chinese direct investments in the BRI partner nations and is the major explanatory variable. For a more nuanced understanding of how China's direct investment has affected climate change vulnerability, the study normalizes the data by each country's total economic production (Li and Zhang, 2020). This helps to account for variations in economic size.

Growth in wealth and political stability are two potential mediating processes that are also examined in the analysis (Mu et al., 2020). Wei et al. (2022) found a positive correlation between national income levels and climate shift vulnerability risks, suggesting that an increase in income may help mitigate these risks. This contradicts the existing research, which often emphasizes the poverty reduction effects of BRI investments on income levels in partner countries. The research uses GDP per capita (adjusted for purchasing power parity) as a measure of income growth.

This study uses the political stability index from the WGIs database to measure the level of political stability in countries participating in the BRI. This index is commonly used in existing research and acts as a control variable (Graham et al., 2018).

In addition, the study takes into consideration a number of control variables that help to account for different factors that influence a country's susceptibility to climate change risks. These variables include economic aggregate (log of gross domestic product [LGDP]), the quadratic term of economic aggregate (GDP2), population density (Popdensity), urbanization rate (Urbanrate), forest area coverage (Forestrate), government efficiency (GovernE) as measured by the index from the WGIs database, agricultural land area (Agricul), and the frequency of climate-related natural disasters (Disasters) as measured by the EMDAT Global Disaster Database.

Research model

The proposed model to test Hypothesis 1 examines the impact of direct investment under China's One Belt, One Road (OBOR) initiative on the climate change vulnerability risk of partner countries. The model can be represented as follows:

Equation (1):VULNERi,t=β0+β1CFDIi,t−1+β2LGDPi,t−1+β3GDPi,t−12+β4Popdensityi,t−1+β5Urbanratei,t−1+β6Forestratei,t−1+β7GovernEi,t−1+β8Agriculi,t−1+β9Disastersi,t−1+Nationi+Yeart+ϵitGiven that annual climate change vulnerability indicators are assessed at the end of each calendar year, the potential impact of the explanatory and control variables is subject to a certain temporal lag. To mitigate potential endogeneity concerns and to accurately capture the causal relationships, all explanatory and control variables in the model are lagged by one period. The empirical model incorporates both country-specific and time-specific dummy variables, denoted as Nationi and Yeart respectively, to control for any unobserved heterogeneity within countries and years. 0β0 represents the constant term, while β1−β9 are the regression coefficients corresponding to the explanatory and control variables. The subscripts i and t denote the country and year, respectively, and ɛit represents the error term. A significantly negative coefficient for β1 would lend support to Hypothesis 1.

To examine Hypothesis 2 and Hypothesis 3, the intermediary effects of direct investment within China's OBOR initiative are explored through a mediation analysis. This analysis will elucidate the underlying mechanisms through which direct investment influences the outcomes of interest. Accordingly, the following model is specified:

Equation (2):Mediatorsji,t=β0+β1CFDIi,t−1+β2LGDPi,t−1+β3GPD2i,t−1+β4Popdensityi,t−1+β5Urbanratei,t−1+β6Forestratei,t−1+β7GovernEi,t−1+β8Agriculi,t−1+β9Disastersi,t−1+Nationi+Yeart+εitEquation (3):VULNERABILITYi,t=β0+β1CFDIi,t−1+β2LGDPi,t−1+β3GPD2i,t−1+β4Popdensityi,t−1+β5Urbanratei,t−1+β6Forestratei,t−1+β7GovernEi,t−1+β8Agriculi,t−1+β9Disastersi,t−1+γj1Mediatorsit+Nationi+Yeart+εitIn this context, mediators represent the variables that mediate the relationship between China's BRI investment and the outcomes of interest. Equation (2) examines the impact of this investment on two mediating variables—income levels and political stability in partner countries. Then, equation (3) integrates these mediating variables into equation (1) to assess their role in influencing the climate change vulnerability risks of partner countries involved in the BRI. If the coefficient β1 in equations (2) and (3) is significant, and γj in equation (3) is also significant, this would suggest the presence of a mediating effect.

Empirical results and discussionDescriptive analysis

The descriptive statistical results of the study's primary variables are presented in the upper half of Table 1. Over the course of the decade from 2004 to 2020, the BRI member nations’ average climate change vulnerability risk ranged from 29.368 to 60.625. A low of about 25.5 was recorded in the 2020 Global ND-GAIN Climate Vulnerability Index. According to these descriptive statistics, the nations that are part of the BRI are relatively vulnerable to climate change, and there are large differences between them.

Table 1.

Descriptive statistics and collinearity test.

While the average stock of Chinese FDI across all nations was a meager 0.273, the wide range of values (more than 18) shows that the size of China's BRI investments fluctuated significantly throughout the time period under consideration. This diversity indicates that beneficiary nations will experience vastly different social and economic effects from these investments.

Also, the nations that are part of the BRI have very different degrees of economic development (LGDP), population density (Popdensity), and urbanization rate (Urbanrate). This indicates that the BRI includes countries in different developmental stages and from different parts of the world. In addition, the average levels of forest coverage (Forestrate) and government effectiveness (GovernE) were shown to be low, indicating that there is plenty of opportunity for BRI partner nations to enhance ecological protection and government capacity building.

It was necessary to perform a thorough multicollinearity study because the econometric model has numerous mediating factors and control variables. The results of the variance inflation factor (VIF) are shown in the second portion of Table 1. Income, the amount of income in the host country, had the largest VIF among the independent variables at 6.89, which is still below the multicollinearity criterion of 10. An average VIF of 2.57 was recorded for all variables. Therefore, multicollinearity is not anticipated to have a major impact on the following empirical results.

Baseline regression

The results of the baseline regression are displayed in Table 2. First, as shown in column 2, there is a strong negative association between the climate change vulnerability risk of partner countries and the direct impact of China's BRI investments, even after controlling for year-specific and country-specific fixed variables. This lends preliminary credence to Hypothesis 1, which states that a country's susceptibility to climate change decreases in correlation with the amount of direct investment from China.

*p < 0.10, **p < 0.05, ***p < 0.01; the values in parentheses are robust standard errors.

Column 3 of Table 2 introduces four economic development control variables: economic aggregate (LGDP), economic aggregate quadratic term (GDP2), population density (Popdensity), and urbanization rate (Urbanrate). Following the calculations, the coefficient of CFDI is estimated at −0.115 and is significant at the 5% level, further affirming the positive impact of China's BRI investment on the climate change vulnerability risk of partner countries.

Column 4 presents the regression results according to equation (1). The inclusion of all control variables results in a reduction in the coefficient of CFDI to −0.094, which remains significant at the 5% level, further confirming Hypothesis 1.

Finally, given the relationship between the ND-GAIN vulnerability score and the per capita GDP of each country, the dependent variable VULNER is adjusted for GDP to create DFVULNER, which measures the deviation of a country's ND-GAIN vulnerability score from the expected value based on a regression of GAIN and per capita GDP. Introducing this adjusted variable into equation (1), as displayed in column 5 of Table 2, produces a CFDI coefficient of −0.140, with a significance level of 1%, thereby reinforcing the earlier findings.

Following the calculations, the coefficient of CFDI is estimated at −0.115 and is significant at the 5% level, further affirming the positive impact of China's BRI investment on the climate change vulnerability risk of partner countries.

Introducing this adjusted variable into equation (1), as displayed in column 5 of Table 2, produces a CFDI coefficient of −0.140, with a significance level of 1%, thereby reinforcing the earlier findings.

Robustness checkRobustness analysis

In order to ensure that the empirical results are trustworthy, the results of a battery of robustness tests are described in Table 3. A change was made to the measurement approach to test robustness initially, in recognition of potential bias in using stock data to measure China's BRI investment. Using the same variable structure, we developed the explanatory variable CFDII and substituted flow data for the stock data of China's direct investment in BRI partner nations. The effects of the adjusted explanatory variable on the vulnerability risk of climate change and GDP-adjusted vulnerability risk of BRI partner countries are shown in Columns 2 and 3 of Table 3. The results show that CFDII's coefficient is consistently negative and statistically significant at the 1% level, which means that the main conclusion holds up even when the explanatory variable's measurement varies. In order to test for robustness, we also looked at additional climate change risk indices as potential markers of climatic vulnerability. Equation (1) now uses Germanwatch's Climate Risk Index instead of VULNER. The index ranks the countries according to the degree of damage caused by climate and meteorological loss events (such as storms, floods, and heat waves) from 2005 to 2019. Values below 1 indicate modest levels of climate change risk, whereas values above 1 indicate increased economic and demographic losses owing to such catastrophes. We added the Climate Risk Index's one-period lag as a control variable because the total number of countries has an effect on the rankings of individual countries. As anticipated, the results (column 4 of Table 3) demonstrate a CFDI coefficient that is statistically significant at the 10% level. Supporting the robustness of the primary results are the moderate degree of significance, which may be attributable to a limited sample size.

Table 3.

Robustness test regression results.

*p < 0.10, **p < 0.05, ***p < 0.01; Values in parentheses are robust standard errors.

Lastly, the results from the last two columns of Table 2 were recalculated, since China's FDI in the BRI started late, with low investment before 2005. Therefore, the sample period was limited to 2006–2020. Regression results for the same variables are shown in columns 5 and 6 of Table 3. The CFDI coefficient is still significantly negative, as it was in Table 2, which supports the robustness of Hypothesis 1.

Endogeneity treatment

Concerns concerning reverse causality arise from the fact that climate change vulnerability risks are highly correlated with nations’ natural and socioeconomic characteristics. As a result, these risks may impact the attractiveness of BRI partner countries to Chinese investors. The research uses an instrumental variable strategy to deal with this possible endogeneity. In particular, counts of Chinese expatriates participating in economic collaboration with BRI nations and number of terrorist acts per country were used as instrumental variables in a two-stage least squares regression. Table 4 shows the regression findings. As with the last two columns of Table 2, columns 2 and 3 employ the quantity of terrorist activity in each country as an instrumental variable. At the 1% level of significance, the coefficient for CFDI is negative; as an instrumental variable, columns 4 and 5 use the number of Chinese expatriates involved in economic collaboration with BRI nations. Despite a decreased significance level, the CFDI coefficient is still negative.

Table 4.

Instrumental variable regression results.

*p < 0. 10, ***p < 0. 01; the values in parentheses are robust standard errors.

Both instrumental variables were found to be valid after passing the weak instrument test, as seen in the last two rows of Table 4. Therefore, the instrumental factors that were chosen are suitable for the study. The results show that China's BRI investment considerably reduces the risks of climate change vulnerability in partner nations, confirming Hypothesis 1, even after accounting for possible endogeneity difficulties caused by reverse causation.

Mechanism analysis

Theoretically, the countries that are part of China's BRI may become less susceptible to the effects of climate change if the investments made by China in these countries raise their incomes and make them more resilient. These countries would be even less vulnerable to the effects of climate change if these investments reduced political and social instability, which in turn reduced the severity of losses caused by natural disasters. The effects of income growth and political stability, which are both attributed to BRI investments, are mirrored by these two impact paths.

Using regression analysis with equations (2) and (3), we explore the roles of the political stability index and per capita gross national income as proxy variables for the two mechanisms discussed earlier. Table 5 displays the outcomes of this analysis of mechanisms: column 2 shows that the income levels of partner nations have been positively affected by China's BRI investments, implying that the host country's income levels have been enhanced by direct investment from China. Column 4 shows that the political stability of partner nations is positively impacted by BRI investments, further proving that FDI from China helps to improve the political stability of host countries.

Table 5.

Mechanism analysis regression results.

**p < 0.05, ***p < 0.01; the values in parentheses are robust standard errors.

The results of equation (3) with the two mediating variables included are shown in columns 3 and 5 of Table 5. The coefficients for Income and PoliticsS are both substantially negative at the 1% level, but CFDI's coefficient is still significantly negative. When considering the effects of BRI investments on partner nations’ vulnerability risks to climate change, our results emphasize the critical roles played by levels of political stability and per capita national income. Hypotheses 2 and 3 are confirmed by these partial mediating effects.

Heterogeneity analysis

To look at how the baseline regression findings varied, we ran a heterogeneity analysis. The classification of BRI partner nations into developing and developed categories was the first step in the analysis. Developing countries were defined as having a per capita GDP below US$20,000, while developed countries were defined as having a GDP above US$50,000.

Firsrtly, more than two-thirds of the sample, or lower-income countries, show a negative correlation between Chinese FDI and climate change susceptibility risks (at the 1% level), according to the results shown in columns 2–3 of Table 6. While rich nations also feel the effects, the coefficient's lower significance level indicates that developing nations are more vulnerable to the dangers associated with climate change as a result of BRI investment. This result is in line with the mechanism analysis, since developing nations are more susceptible to the income growth benefits of CFDI due to their higher poverty rates, worse socioeconomic conditions, and greater vulnerability to climate change.

Table 6.

Regression results of heterogeneity analysis.

*p < 0.10, **p < 0.05, ***p < 0.01; the values in parentheses are robust standard errors.

Secondly, the effect of direct investment may be affected by the proximity of the two countries, which in turn shapes their foreign investment policies. The nations that are members of the BRI were categorized into two groups: those that are neighbors of China (both geographically and in terms of maritime proximity) and those that are not. The results of the regression for these subsamples are shown in columns 4 and 5 of Table 6. At the 5% level of significance, BRI investment has a strongly negative effect on neighboring countries but no effect on non-neighboring countries. This suggests that the lowered investment risk, transaction costs, and overall impact of BRI investments on lowering climate change sensitivity risks in adjacent countries are more noticeable.

Thirdly, the research took into account the strength of friendly and trade links between the two countries, which might affect the amount and impact of FDI. Countries that are part of the BRI were categorized as either having or not having signed a free trade area agreement with China. As a result of improved business climates, stronger political mutual trust, reduced communication costs between the two countries, and closer economic linkages, China's FDI tends to rise in countries that have signed free trade area agreements. Consequently, BRI investment may have a greater impact on climate change vulnerability risks in such countries. Columns 6 and 7 of Table 6 display the regression results for these two groups. The findings demonstrate that countries with free trade agreements experience more significant effects from Chinese investment, supporting the study's conjecture.

Analysis of dimensional indicators of climate change vulnerability

Three important aspects of a country's vulnerability to climate change are its exposure to hazards, its sensitivity to disasters caused by climate change, and its adaptive capability to handle the consequences of climate change. These dimensions are evaluated by the ND-GAIN Vulnerability Index. The exposure component gauges the susceptibility of ecological and environmental systems worldwide to catastrophic climate change disasters, with the main drivers being the inherent and stable environmental circumstances of each nation. Adjustments to the ND-GAIN assessment framework are brought about by changes in the sensitivity dimension, which takes into account a nation's dependence on sectors hit hard by climate-related disasters, including the percentage of impacts caused by climate change and the responsiveness of the economic sector to these kinds of occurrences. A country's social adaptation to climate change is a reflection of its ability to respond to the harm that climate change disasters inflict by mobilizing social resources, which can vary over time.

We examine the effect of China's BRI investments on the three categories of climate change vulnerability in partner nations by breaking down the ND-GAIN Vulnerability Index into these three dimensions (Table 7). As shown in Columns 2 and 3, the nations that are co-building the BRI with China can greatly mitigate the dangers associated with climate change.

These dimensions are evaluated by the ND-GAIN Vulnerability Index. The exposure component gauges the susceptibility of ecological and environmental systems worldwide to catastrophic climate change disasters, with the main drivers being the inherent and stable environmental circumstances of each nation. Adjustments to the ND-GAIN assessment framework are brought about by changes in the sensitivity dimension, which takes into account a nation's dependence on sectors hit hard by climate-related disasters, including the percentage of impacts caused by climate change and the responsiveness of the economic sector to these kinds of occurrences. A country's social adaptation to climate change is a reflection of its ability to respond to the harm that climate change disasters inflict by mobilizing social resources, which can vary over time.

We examine the effect of China's BRI investments on the three categories of climate change vulnerability in partner nations by breaking down the ND-GAIN Vulnerability Index into these three dimensions (Table 7). As shown in columns 2 and 3, the nations that are co-building the BRI with China can greatly mitigate the dangers associated with climate change.

Column 4 shows that the societal adaptive capacity to climate change in co-building nations is not considerably improved by China's BRI investments, which increases risk exposure and disaster susceptibility. For this reason, China's BRI expenditures mainly help partner nations become less vulnerable to risks and disasters, rather than more adaptable to climate change. The main reason for this is that the BRI is more concerned with promoting economic development and enjoying its fruits than with combating climate change head-on. One unintended consequence of China's FDI is the mitigation of climate change sensitivity issues in other countries. The nations’ adaptive capacities to climate change are not, however, targeted or improved by these investments.

Both the CFDI and AllFDI coefficients are positive, according to the dependent variable analysis. However, only the AllFDI coefficient is significant at the 1% level. Results like these show that China's BRI investments do not have the same impact as total FDI, which can raise carbon emissions per capita in nations along the route. To rephrase, the “emissions transfer” problem has not worsened as a result of China's investments in the BRI. Since the over-reliance on fossil fuels is a major contributor to the world's carbon emissions problem, measuring a country's energy intensity can tell us a lot about its energy transition and its attempts to cut carbon emissions. To further support the absence of a emissions transfer issue, columns 4 and 5 analyze the effect of China's BRI investments on energy intensity levels in co-building countries. The results demonstrate that neither total FDI nor the BRI investments have a significant impact on these levels.

Table 8’s last two columns provide a direct evaluation of the carbon emissions and FDI levels of BRI nations. Both the CFDI and AllFDI coefficients are statistically significant at the 10% and 5% levels, respectively. Therefore, carbon emissions in co-building countries are substantially increased by total FDI, but they can be somewhat reduced by the resources of China's FDI. Investments made as part of China's BRI have not worsened the emissions transfer problem, as this result shows.

Investments in China's BRI can, in a nutshell, make co-building nations less susceptible to climate change concerns without substantially increasing their carbon emissions levels, and they can even help reduce those emissions. Green investment methods, the notion of sharing development outcomes, and active investments in green infrastructure, renewable energy, and bioenergy initiatives are largely responsible for this. Investment projects’ profitability and sustainability are taken into account in this strategy. This discovery provides strong evidence in favor of the study's fourth hypothesis and, in response to Western media's baseless critiques, highlights the environmentally friendly basis of China's BRI.

Supplementary analysis

The investments made by China as part of its BRI have long been the target of criticism from some Western nations, which claim that they enable “pollution transfer.” The positive effects of lowering partner countries’ climate vulnerability might be diminished by this unflattering depiction. Moreover, these claims may be part of a larger effort to delegitimize the BRI by implying that, in return for reducing the risks associated with climate change, the initiative causes partner states to raise their carbon emissions.

We must give facts to refute these accusations and show that China's BRI investments can be beneficial without producing “emissions leakage.” This study seeks to prove that the investments made by China through the BRI successfully reduce vulnerability to climate change without increasing carbon emissions. Three linked variables were evaluated to estimate the impact of BRI investments on carbon emissions: total carbon emissions, energy intensity, and per capita carbon emissions. In addition, the research contrasts the results of AllFDI in partner nations with those of CFDI. The outcomes of the regression analysis are displayed in Table 8. The correlation between BRI funding and carbon emissions per capita in participating nations is discussed in columns 2 and 3. While the AllFDI coefficient is statistically significant at the 1% level, the CFDI coefficient is positive as well, according to the results. As a result, it appears that China's BRI investments have not worsened emissions transfer, even though total FDI can raise per capita carbon emissions levels. The main reason for global carbon emissions is the excessive consumption of fossil fuels. A country's energy intensity can tell us how much energy it relies on for economic development and whether or not it is considering switching to cleaner energy sources. Energy intensity in partner nations is unaffected by either CFDI or AllFDI, according to columns 4 and 5, which analyze the effect of BRI investments on this metric. This lends credence to the idea that China's BRI investments do not involve any emissions transfer problem.

Total carbon emissions in partner countries and their connection with FDI are evaluated in the final two columns of Table 8. At the 5% level, the AllFDI coefficient is strongly positive, meaning that carbon emissions are going up. However, at the 10% level, the CFDI coefficient is significantly negative, meaning that direct investment from China can only go down in emissions by a certain amount.

Finally, without substantially raising carbon emission levels in partner nations, China's BRI investments can lessen climate vulnerability concerns and might possibly help bring about reductions in carbon emissions. This result is in line with the sustainable development goals and green investment principles of China's BRI. While disproving baseless assertions made by Western media about China's BRI, this finding provides strong support for the study's fourth hypothesis.

Conclusions and policy recommendations

Focusing on the effects of income growth and political stability, this study uses econometric approaches to examine how China's BRI investments affect the susceptibility risks of climate change in participating nations. This study takes a more holistic view, based on the idea of a shared human destiny, as opposed to earlier work that mostly focused on the economic effects of BRI. In doing so, it hopes to fill a knowledge vacuum about BRI's beneficial impact on combating global climate change and improve comprehension of its accomplishments. The study debunks Western nations’ unfounded claims of emissions leakage and highlights the environmentally friendly nature of China's BRI projects by offering proof.

There are multiple major takeaways from the research. First, the degree to which partner nations are vulnerable to climate change and their capacity to respond to it have both been significantly diminished by China's BRI investments. Second, partner nations’ economic development levels, closeness to China, and trade links with China determine the extent to which BRI investments reduce risk. Particularly affected are emerging nations, those bordering China, and those that have free trade agreements with China. Lastly, investments in the BRI boost political stability and economic growth in partner nations, which in turn decreases the likelihood of climate change-related losses and increases resilience. In addition to reducing climate change sensitivity risks, the fourth benefit of China's BRI investments is that they have no influence on the overall, per capita, or energy intensity of carbon emissions in the partner nations. An international effort is required to combat climate change, which is a critical issue on a global scale. Promoting global governance on climate change is an important aspect of the BRI mission to create a global community that shares a common future with all people. Several policy proposals are made to advance this goal throughout the report. Prioritizing the BRI's function as a “green path” and “path to solving global climate issues,” raising consciousness about the need for green transformation and low-carbon growth, should be the first step in whatever comes next. This involves reassuring partner nations about the BRI's ability to improve global climate governance and encouraging them to work together more closely by addressing their concerns. The BRI should also act in accordance with the win-win cooperation principle, ensuring that partner nations benefit from high-quality development while also concentrating on project sustainability and profitability. Economic development, higher incomes, and more political stability can be achieved by coordinating BRI projects with the investment requirements of partner nations and China's industrial capabilities. This will increase their ability to combat climate change.

Contrary to what some Western countries have said, China's investment in the BRI not only mitigates the dangers of climate change vulnerability for partner countries but also avoids the emissions transfer problem. In the future, China's business investments in the BRI should keep focusing on green and growing industries in the countries that are partners. In order to help partner nations with their energy transitions and industrial transformations, BRI investments can tap into China's advanced renewable energy and new energy vehicle industries. In pursuit of carbon neutrality and the larger goals of the BRI, this will be crucial.

urn:contentItem:6FKS-0DN3-RWD6-X4BX-00000-00Studies from Institute for Global Environmental Strategies Yield New Information about Sustainability Research (Urban Green Infrastructure Planning In Jaipur, India: a Gis-based Suitability Model for Semi-arid Cities)2025-04-18T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T05:43:01ZLexisNexisSUSTAINABILITY RESEARCHStudies from Institute for Global Environmental Strategies Yield New Information about Sustainability Research (Urban Green Infrastructure Planning In Jaipur, India: a Gis-based Suitability Model for Semi-arid Cities)


2025 APR 18 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Japan Daily Report -- Investigators publish new report on Sustainability Research. According to news reporting out of Kanagawa, Japan, by NewsRx editors, research stated, "Urbanization in Jaipur, India, has led to a 42% decline in green cover over the past two decades, exacerbating urban heat, air pollution, groundwater depletion, and reduced livability. Green Infrastructure (GI) offers a sustainable solution, but effective implementation requires robust, data-driven strategies."


Financial support for this research came from Japan Society for the Promotion of Science.
Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from Institute for Global Environmental Strategies, "This study employs geospatial technologies-GIS, remote sensing, and Multi-Criteria Decision Analysis (MCDA)-to develop a suitability model for Urban Green Infrastructure (UGI) planning. Using an entropy-based weighting approach, the model integrates environmental factors, including the Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI), which fell by 18% between 2000 and 2020; Land Surface Temperature (LST), which increased by 1.8 degrees C; soil moisture; precipitation; slope; and land use/land cover (LULC). Proximity to water bodies was found to be a critical determinant of suitability, whereas land surface temperature and soil moisture played significant roles in determining UGI feasibility. The results were validated using NDVI trends and comparative analysis with prior studies so as to ensure accuracy and robustness. The suitability analysis reveals that 35% of Jaipur's urban area, particularly peri-urban regions and river corridors, is highly suitable for UGI interventions, thereby presenting significant opportunities for urban cooling, flood mitigation, and enhanced ecosystem services. These findings align with India's National Urban Policy Framework (2018) and the UN Sustainable Development Goal 11, supporting climate resilience and sustainable urban development."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "This geospatial approach provides a scalable methodology for integrating green spaces into urban planning frameworks across rapidly urbanizing cities."
For more information on this research see: Urban Green Infrastructure Planning In Jaipur, India: a Gis-based Suitability Model for Semi-arid Cities. Sustainability, 2025;17(6):2420. Sustainability can be contacted at: Mdpi, St Alban-Anlage 66, Ch-4052 Basel, Switzerland.
Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Pankaj Kumar, Institute for Global Environmental Strategies, Kanagawa 2400115, Japan. Additional authors for this research include Ritu Nathawat, Saurabh Kumar Gupta, Suraj Kumar Singh, Bhartendu Sajan, Shruti Kanga, Shamik Chakraborty, Asif Marazi, Mohamed Yehia Abouleish, Gowhar Meraj and Tarig Ali.
The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.3390/su17062420. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.
Keywords for this news article include: Kanagawa, Japan, Asia, Sustainability Research, Institute for Global Environmental Strategies.

urn:contentItem:6F73-M0C3-RRPX-64KK-00000-00Findings from University of Tsukuba Broaden Understanding of Wind Energy (Assessing Wind Power Generation Potential Over South Asia Using Wind Speed Observation and Reanalysis Datasets)2025-02-27T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T05:43:01ZLexisNexisENERGY - WIND ENERGYFindings from University of Tsukuba Broaden Understanding of Wind Energy (Assessing Wind Power Generation Potential Over South Asia Using Wind Speed Observation and Reanalysis Datasets)


2025 FEB 27 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Japan Daily Report -- Investigators discuss new findings in Energy - Wind Energy. According to news reporting from Ibaraki, Japan, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, "Wind energy has exceptional and untapped potential in South Asia, a region characterized by a diverse climate and geography. The novelty of this research lies in using systematic selection threshold criteria, ensuring a comprehensive representation of wind speed patterns to determine wind energy generation potential classification and standardize wind anomaly over diverse topographic and climatic conditions of South Asia."


Funders for this research include Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology, Japan (MEXT), Microsoft.
The news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from the University of Tsukuba, "Further, using reanalysis products (ERA5, JRA55, NCEP/NCAR), a multi-reanalysis ensemble (MRE), and wind speed trends, this work systematically evaluates the reliability and accuracy of the performance of reanalysis products to perceive uncertainty in reanalysis products. For this determination, a 10 m above ground level (AGL) of wind speed was utilized for 1973-2005. A high percentage of stations with missing wind speed values is identified in the study, emphasizing the importance of data quality. Overall, providing strong correlations, low bias, and close alignment with observed data, JRA55 is a reliable choice for wind energy assessments and climate studies. Also, the research reveals a downward trend in annual mean wind speed (- 0.010 ms-1\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$${\text{year) <. >{-1}$$\end{document}) in South Asia, aligning with the global terrestrial stilling phenomenon, although significant localized variations exist. The findings based on the localized regions, such as the Hyderabad Airport station, offer Excellent prospects for developing wind energy yield when classified. The reasons for inconsistencies between reanalysis products and observations are examined. A robust systematic threshold criteria research method is delineated to enhance data quality, revealing insights into spatial coverage, station selection, and biases."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "Ultimately, the study contributed to South Asia's climate resilience, policymakers, regional climate dynamics, and sustainable development of renewable energy sources."
This research has been peer-reviewed.
For more information on this research see: Assessing Wind Power Generation Potential Over South Asia Using Wind Speed Observation and Reanalysis Datasets. Stochastic Environmental Research and Risk Assessment, 2025. Stochastic Environmental Research and Risk Assessment can be contacted at: Springer, One New York Plaza, Suite 4600, New York, Ny, United States. (Springer - www.springer.com; Stochastic Environmental Research and Risk Assessment - www.springerlink.com/content/1436-3240/)
Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Muhammad Abid Khan, University of Tsukuba, Graduate School of Science and Technology, Dept. of Engineering Mechanics and Energy, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 3058577, Japan. Additional authors for this research include Koji Dairaku and Saurabh Kelkar.
The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1007/s00477-025-02918-0. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.

urn:contentItem:6DDC-W7J1-F07D-T046-00000-00NEC participates in COP29 climate change conference2024-11-12T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T05:43:01ZLexisNexisNEC participates in COP29 climate change conferenceTOKYO

TOKYO, Nov 12, 2024 - (JCN Newswire) - NEC Corporation (NEC; TSE: 6701) is participating in the 29th Conference of the Parties (COP29) to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC), held in Azerbaijan from November 11 to 22, 2024 with a keynote speech in the UGIH Pavilion, the host organization of the conference, and a seminar organized by Japan's Ministry of the Environment and the Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications in the Japan Pavilion.

In the keynote session, Motoo Nishihara, Corporate EVP, CTO and Head of the GIBU, NEC Corporation, will introduce progress in the adaptive finance business as well as use cases in collaboration with domestic and international companies, under the theme of "Promotion of adaptive finance through digital technology and co-creation activities." Nishihara will also participate in a seminar hosted by Japan's Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications (MIC) at the COP29 Japan Pavilion, where he will give a presentation for government officials from participating countries, international organizations, and companies. He will also participate in a panel discussion among public and private sector officials on how to improve ICT network environments (power saving) and ICT utilization (visualization of global warming countermeasures, etc.).

In addition, at a seminar hosted by the Ministry of the Environment in the Japan Pavilion, Miki Sato, General Manager of NEC's GX Business Development Management Division, will present a model case of an adaptation business promoting the introduction of early warning systems for natural disasters.

UGIH Pavilion (keynote/panel discussion)

Session Title: Advancing Climate Adaptation with Digital Technology:

Fostering "Pilots of Excellence" in Climate Resilience through Partnerships

Date: Friday, November 15, 2024, 21:30-22:30 (Japan time - local time 16:30-17:30)

Speaker: Motoo Nishihara, Corporate EVP, CTO and Head of the GIBU, NEC Corporation

Seminar Overview:

There is an urgent need to address adaptation projects in preparation for natural disasters and to realize a sustainable society. In order to promote investment in adaptation projects by financial institutions, there is a need for evaluation of the economic value to be gained from the implementation of adaptation measures, and for public-private partnerships. In this seminar, we will discuss the progress of adaptation finance projects in collaboration with financial institutions since COP28, use cases in Japan and internationally based on knowledge gained from co-creation and demonstration with private companies in Japan, and the advancement of adaptation measures using advanced digital technologies, including NEC's satellite-based solutions (earth observation data), AI data and AI (image recognition and LLM).

View the following URL for detail: www.youtube.com/watch?v=-HCyMcGj4XY

Japan Pavilion, Seminar hosted by Ministry of the Environment

Seminar Title: Further Promotion of EWS and New Collaborations in the Asia-Pacific Region

Date: Saturday, November 16, 2024, 15:00-16:15 (Japan time - local time: 10:00-11:15)

Speakers: Soichi Noguchi (video appearance),

Director and CTO, Adaptive Finance Consortium,

International Institute for Social and Economic Research, Inc.

Miki Sato

NEC Cross Industry Business Unit

General Manager, GX Business Development Division

NEC Corporation

Seminar Summary:

The Ministry of the Environment of Japan is working on the introduction of Early Warning Systems (EWS) for natural disasters to Asia-Pacific countries.

The EWS Council, which is comprised of the Ministry of the Environment of Japan and other Japanese private sector companies, has been working to address climate change issues in the Asia-Pacific region. In this seminar, we will introduce the progress and achievements of the EWS Council and propose new adaptation measures developed through collaboration among Japanese private companies in the fields of weather information services, insurance, and finance, which are different from each other in terms of business type, in order to create new synergies. Discussions will also be held with practicing (potential) countries to promote the introduction of EWS.

View the following URL for detail: Enhancing Early Warning Systems (EWS) Deployment & Further Collaboration in Asia-Pacific | COP29 JAPAN PAVILION - Ministry of the Environment

Japan Pavilion: Seminar hosted by the Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications

Seminar Title: ICT x Green Seminar

Date: Saturday, November 16, 2024, 16:45-18:00 (Japan time - local time: 11:45-13:00)

Speaker: Motoo Nishihara, Corporate EVP, CTO and Head of the GIBU, NEC Corporation

Seminar Summary:

While digitization is rapidly advancing in the world today, and there is a shift toward socioeconomic activities that rely on the use of the Internet, many people, especially in developing countries, are unable to enjoy the benefits of digitization due to a lack of telecommunications infrastructure, especially in rural areas. Under the theme of "ICT x Green," the Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications (MIC) is promoting the development of future ICT network environments that contribute to countering global warming and reducing the burden on the global environment (power saving).

Presentations by government officials from participating countries, international organizations, and business representatives, as well as panel discussions among public and private sector participants, will be held to discuss how to promote the use of ICT (e.g., visualization of global warming countermeasures) and the use of ICT (e.g., the visualization of global warming countermeasures).

For more details, please visit the COP29 Japan Pavilion website. See also ICT X Green Seminar | COP29 JAPAN PAVILION - Ministry of the Environment

NEC will also exhibit in the Japan Pavilion as part of the Adaptive Finance Consortium launched with Mitsui Sumitomo Insurance Company, Limited.

About NEC Corporation

NEC Corporation has established itself as a leader in the integration of IT and network technologies while promoting the brand statement of "Orchestrating a brighter world." NEC enables businesses and communities to adapt to rapid changes taking place in both society and the market as it provides for the social values of safety, security, fairness and efficiency to promote a more sustainable world where everyone has the chance to reach their full potential. For more information, visit NEC at https://www.nec.com.

Source: NEC Corporation

urn:contentItem:695S-1CV1-F12F-F1ND-00000-00X POST ON LIBYA FLOODS USES VIDEO OF 2021 MUDSLIDE DISASTER IN JAPAN2023-09-14T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T05:43:01ZLexisNexisX POST ON LIBYA FLOODS USES VIDEO OF 2021 MUDSLIDE DISASTER IN JAPAN

TOKYO, Sept. 14 -- NHK World issued the following news:

A trending social media post on the floods in Libya uses a video of a deadly mudslide that occurred in Japan in 2021.

More than 5,000 people have reportedly died in the floods in eastern Libya that were triggered by heavy rains on Monday.

A post on X, formerly known as Twitter, says, in English: "Heartbreaking to see the havoc caused by flash floods in Libya. It's yet another stark reminder of the urgent need for global action on climate resilience and preparedness." It accompanies, without a caption, a video showing houses being washed away in a mudslide. The video actually shows the disaster that took place in the resort town of Atami, Japan, in July, 2021. More than two dozen people died.

The same video has also been posted, without a caption, on another X account, with the hashtag #Libya.

A number of X users have spotted the misleading video, and pointed out that the video is not about Libya, but Japan.

The video appears to be yet another example of how misleading, or outright false information can spread quickly online during a natural disaster.

In the aftermath of wildfires on the Hawaiian island of Maui in August, some online posts showed totally unrelated images and made baseless claims that the fires had been started deliberately.

When a strong earthquake hit Kumamoto City in Japan in 2016, fake news was posted online that a lion had escaped from a zoo in the city. It was accompanied by a video taken in another country. For any query with respect to this article or any other content requirement, please contact Editor at contentservices@htlive.com
